Award.AwardTitle: SHF: Small: Modern Web Applications without Callbacks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration: The project will investigate a new programming model for web programming. Modern Web programming practice typically uses a pattern referred to as "callbacks," which obscures the connection between parts of the Web display and the application logic that corresponds to those parts. This makes Web application development more difficult, expensive and error prone. These problems are, of course, passed on to Web application users. The project's hypothesis is that programming without callbacks will lead to more reliable web applications. Specifically, this research will apply functional reactive data-flow programming techniques to Web 2.0 programming. The first challenge is whether realistic web applications can be programmed at all without callbacks; further progress will lead to improved programming models and tools for the development of web applications. The new programming approaches will be evaluated by assessing the difficulty of programming existing and new web applications while also assessing performance and other measures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The grant, "Modern Web Applications without Callbacks" led to nine scientific publications. The first set of these focused on the problem of modeling efficient Web applications without using callbacks. The key challenges were efficiently compiling to traditional architectures (OOPSLA 2010) and ensuring that the different components of the Web applications behaved properly together (ICFP 2011). Our study of the semantics of these applications led to a need to more fundamentally understanding the semantic models employed (ASPLS 2011 and POPL 2012). As we continued to analyze the applications, it was necessary to investigate probabilistic aspects of their construction (IFL 2011 and FLOPS 2012). Finally, we generalized our Web results to any message passing architecture (VMCAI 2012 and ASE 2013).

 

The results of this project were not only published in public journals and conference proceedings, but the software components of them are freely available on our Web sites under open source licenses for all to use. In fact, some of our techniques, such as the compilation technique have already been used in industrial products.

 

In summary, through this project were able to increase the reliability and efficiency of Web applications that are split between a server component and the a client component, as nearly all Web applications are.
